{
  "article_text": [
    "the restricted quantum group , @xmath0 , for @xmath3 , @xmath4 , is a finite dimensional quotient of @xmath5 with non - semisimple representation theory , and was conjectured in @xcite to have a representation category equivalent to the representation category of the @xmath6 logarithmic conformal field theory .",
    "an equivalence as abelian categories was proven in @xcite , however @xcite showed that @xmath0 has modules whose tensor product does not commute , and so the category is not braided .",
    "this example does not appear in the subcategory generated by irreducible modules , which is the focus of our construction .",
    "+ planar algebras are a type of diagrammatic algebra first introduced as an axiomatization of the standard invariant of subfactors , and shown to have close relations to statistical mechanics and knot theory .",
    "the standard example of a planar algebra is the temperley - lieb algebra , which can be constructed from @xmath5 , as a description of @xmath7 , where @xmath8 is a two - dimensional irreducible module @xcite .",
    "we aim to generalize this construction to the restricted quantum group .",
    "+ the @xmath0 planar algebra is a diagrammatic description of @xmath1 , where @xmath8 is a two dimensional @xmath0 module . it was shown in @xcite that for @xmath9 , this is isomorphic to the temperley - lieb algebra with parameter @xmath10 , and for @xmath11 contains extra generators , @xmath12 and @xmath13 , @xmath14 .",
    "we define these generators explicitly in terms of the @xmath0 action which allow us to prove combinatorially a number of relations on them .",
    "the main focus of the paper is the relations in theorem [ thm ] and their proofs .",
    "we also conjecture a formula for the dimensions of the planar algebra at the end of section [ uq ] .",
    "some of these relations were previously proven in @xcite , however we include proofs here for completeness .",
    "other relations in theorem [ thm ] generalize their results for @xmath15 .",
    "+ it was conjectured in @xcite that @xmath12 and @xmath13 , along with the temperley - lieb algebra , generate @xmath1 .",
    "we do not claim to have a proof of this , although we note that @xmath16 and @xmath17 give maps between the highest and lowest weight copies of @xmath18 appearing in the decomposition of @xmath19 , which is where we would expect any new generators to appear , and so lends evidence to support the conjecture .",
    "further , we conjecture that the relations in theorem [ thm ] , along with generalizations of relations [ eq:15 ] and [ eq:16 ] , fully describe @xmath1 . the generalizations of relations [ eq:15 ] and [ eq:16 ] are sums over all diagrams containing @xmath12 and @xmath13 in @xmath1 , and will be described in more detail in a future paper @xcite .",
    "the reasoning for this conjecture comes from considering diagrammatic descriptions of morphisms between modules , which can be considered as the reasoning behind many relations . hence knowing the diagrammatic descriptions of all such morphisms suggests that the possibility of there being any unknown relations is less likely .",
    "these diagrammatic descriptions will be detailed in @xcite , and are also described in @xcite . + the paper is outlined as follows : in section @xmath20 , we review the definition of @xmath0 , along with the modules , fusion rules , and module homomorphisms relevant to our construction , as well as giving details on the dimensions of the planar algebra . in section @xmath21",
    ", we introduce the planar algebra construction , and define the generators @xmath22 and @xmath23 , along with a number of relations on them .",
    "the proofs of the @xmath0 relations are given in section @xmath24 .",
    "we record a number of combinatorial identities used in the proofs in the appendix . for more detailed proofs ,",
    "see @xcite .",
    "for @xmath25 , @xmath26 , and @xmath27 , the restricted quantum group @xmath0 over a field @xmath28 is the hopf algebra generated by @xmath29 subject to the relations : @xmath30 and coproduct @xmath31 , counit @xmath32 , and antipode @xmath33 : @xmath34 the modules for @xmath0 were given in @xcite , and the modules relevant to our construction consist of the following : @xmath35 simple modules , @xmath36 , @xmath37 , two simple projective modules @xmath38 and @xmath35 non - simple indecomposable projective modules @xmath39 . for the simple modules @xmath36 ,",

    "the projective modules @xmath39 , @xmath37 , for a given choice of @xmath45 , can be given in terms of the basis @xmath46 .",
    "the action of @xmath0 is given by : @xmath47[s - i]a_{i-1 } & eb_{i}&=\\pm[i][s - i]b_{i-1}+a_{i-1 } & eb_{0}&=x_{p - s-1}\\\\ ex_{j}&=\\mp[j][p - s - j]x_{j-1 } & ey_{j}&=\\mp[j][p - s - j]y_{j-1 } & ey_{0}&=a_{s-1}\\\\ fa_{i}&=a_{i+1 } & fb_{i}&=b_{i+1 } & fb_{s-1}&=y_{0}\\\\ fx_{j}&=x_{j+1 } & fx_{p - s-1}&=a_{0 } & fy_{j}&=y_{j+1}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath48 , @xcite .",

    "the dimensions @xmath81 can be calculated from the @xmath0 fusion rules and homomorphisms , or by use of results in section 4.9 of @xcite .",

    "+   + the module @xmath2 has basis @xmath98 , with @xmath0 action : @xmath99 the action of @xmath0 on @xmath79 is given by use of the coproduct .",
    "+   + we denote by @xmath100 the element of @xmath101 with @xmath102 at positions @xmath103 , and @xmath104 elsewhere .",
    "we also occasionally omit the @xmath105 sign , and combine indices .",
    "for example , @xmath106 .",
    "the elements of @xmath101 can be described in terms of the @xmath107-action on them . for @xmath108 , with @xmath109 , @xmath110 , we call @xmath111 the weight of @xmath112 . alternatively for basis elements we can write this as @xmath113 , and refer to @xmath97 also as the weight .",
    "@xmath101 will then have the set of weights @xmath114 . denoting the set of elements of @xmath101 with weight @xmath115 by @xmath116",
    ", we have @xmath117 .",
    "the weight spaces @xmath118 @xmath119 both have a single element , which we denote by @xmath120 , @xmath121 respectively , and occasionally drop the second index if the context is clear .",
    "we have @xmath122 .",
    "we record a number of combinatorial relations involving @xmath0 and its action on @xmath101 in the appendix .",
    "for detailed introductions to planar algebras , see @xcite .",
    "our construction of the @xmath0 planar algebra is a diagrammatic description of @xmath123 , or more generally , @xmath124 , similar to the constructions of @xcite .",
    "it was shown in @xcite that for @xmath9 , this is isomorphic to the temperley - lieb algebra on @xmath97 points with parameter @xmath125 , and for @xmath11 , @xmath123 contains extra generators , @xmath126 , @xmath127 , which are described in section [ gen ] .",
    "we then prove a number of relations on these generators .",
    "+ diagrammatically , @xmath124 is represented by a box with @xmath97 points along the top , and @xmath128 points along the bottom , where zero points represent a map to / from @xmath129 .",
    "each point on the box is connected to a string , up to isotopy , with strings not allowed to intersect . removing a closed loop from a diagram corresponds to multiplying by @xmath130 .",
    "multiplication of maps is given by adjoining a diagram below another diagram , and smoothing strings .",
    "tensor products are given by by adjoining diagrams side by side .",
    "the identity element in @xmath80 is given by @xmath97 vertical strings .",
    "the identity map @xmath131 is given by an empty box .",
    "we often use a single thick string to represent multiple parallel strings . +   + the _ temperley - lieb algebra _ ,",
    "@xmath132 , is the algebra generated by @xmath133 , @xmath130 , with relations : @xmath134 the _ jones - wenzl projections _ , @xcite , in the temperley - lieb algebra",

    "hence @xmath267 .      from proposition",
    "[ prop 3 ] , we have that the image of @xmath22 and @xmath23 is @xmath73",
    ". however , @xmath73 is irreducible , and does not appear in the decomposition of @xmath79 until @xmath278 . capping or cupping @xmath22 or @xmath23 gives a map between @xmath73 and @xmath279 .",
    "hence this map must be zero .",
    "given @xmath282 , we can write relation [ eq:9 ] explicitly as : @xmath283 using equation [ eq : a6 ] , this simplifies to become : @xmath284 using equation [ eq : a13 ] and [ eq : a14 ] , both sides can be shown to equal @xmath285 .",
    "the proof of relation [ eq:10 ] is similar , with both sides reducing to @xmath286 .",
    "these can be proven diagrammatically from relations [ eq:9 ] and [ eq:10 ] .",
    "we demonstrate the proof for @xmath22 , with @xmath23 following similarly .        hence @xmath22 is rotation invariant . continuing with this , we have :        and so we have the cupping relation .",
    "let @xmath184 denote the clockwise rotation tangle acting on @xmath97 points .    .",
    "]    we want to show the relations @xmath291 , @xmath292 .",
    "these in turn allow the proof of a large number of other relations , and simplification of diagrams containing @xmath22 and @xmath23 .",
    "the proof consists of two steps ; first we show that the diagrams @xmath293 , @xmath294 are linearly dependent , so that the coefficients can be non - zero .",
    "we then give a general solution for the coefficients .",
    "+ we demonstrate the proof for @xmath22 , with the proof for @xmath23 following similarly .",
    "diagrammatically , @xmath291 is given by figure [ fig : rot ] . from this",
    ", we see that there are @xmath295 different diagrams , each of which acts on weight spaces by @xmath296 .",
    "we want to show that the total number of maps acting as @xmath296 is less than @xmath295 .",
    "a list of module maps was given in section [ uq ] , and from this we see that all module maps act as @xmath297 , except for maps between @xmath298 and @xmath299 ( as @xmath73 does not appear in the decomposition of @xmath300 ) . for example , for @xmath301 ,",
    "the maps not preserving weight spaces are :        hence there are two maps acting as @xmath296 , and two acting as @xmath302 .",
    "note that the maps between copies of @xmath303 are a composition of one of these maps with a map preserving weight spaces .",
    "denote the multiplicity of @xmath304 in @xmath300 by @xmath305 . from this , we see that the total number of maps acting as @xmath296 is @xmath306 . by considering module decompositions ,",
    "we find that @xmath307 . hence the diagrams @xmath293 are linearly dependent .",
    "+ consider applying @xmath308 to @xmath291 . as capping off @xmath22",

    "these generalize a large number of relations .",

    "these diagrams describe maps between copies of @xmath330 in @xmath331 .",
    "the partial trace of @xmath22 and @xmath23 can be derived easily from the cupping and capping relations ( relations [ eq:9 ] - [ eq:12 ] ) , and shown to be zero .",
    "we demonstrate the case for alpha :        the partial trace of @xmath192 and @xmath188 is given in figure [ fig : pt ] .",
    "note that the left partial trace follows from the right partial trace and the cupping and capping relations .",
    "we give the proof for @xmath188 , with the proof for @xmath192 following similarly .",
    "+   + consider @xmath332 .",
    "its elements take the form @xmath333 .",
    "we want to apply @xmath334 to this . from section [ subsect 3 ] , we had that given @xmath167 , @xmath272 , @xmath335!)}{([k]!)[p]}f^{k}x_{0,2p-1 }   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ]",
    "we then have : @xmath336!)}{[n+1][p]}\\times\\\\   & \\times\\bigg((f^{n+1}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{0}+q^{n-2p+2}[n+1](f^{n}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{1}\\bigg)\\\\   \\beta(\\alpha(\\rho_{i_{1}, ... ,i_{n},2p-2}\\otimes\\nu_{0}))= & q^{\\big(n(2p-1)-\\frac{1}{2}(n^{2}-n)-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{n}i_{j})\\big)}\\frac{([2p - n-1]!)}{[p]}\\times\\\\   & \\times\\bigg((f^{n}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{0}+q^{n-2p+1}[n](f^{n-1}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{1}\\bigg )   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] note that as @xmath337 , and @xmath22 is zero on @xmath338 for @xmath339 , we will have to treat the case @xmath340 separately",
    ". for @xmath341 , we have : + @xmath342 @xmath343!)}{[n+1][p]}\\times\\\\   & \\times\\bigg((f^{n+1}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{00}+q^{n-2p+2}[n+1](f^{n}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{10}\\bigg)\\\\   & -q^{\\big(n(2p-1)-\\frac{1}{2}(n^{2}-n)-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{n}i_{j})\\big)}\\frac{([2p - n-1]!)}{[p]}\\bigg((f^{n}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{01}+q^{n-2p+1}[n](f^{n-1}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{11}\\bigg )   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] applying @xmath344 , this simplifies to give zero . for the case @xmath340 , as @xmath345",
    ", we have + @xmath346 @xmath347!)}{[p]}\\bigg((f^{p-1}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{01}+q^{-p}[p-1](f^{p-2}x_{0,2p-2})\\otimes\\nu_{11}\\bigg )   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] applying @xmath344 to this , we get : @xmath348!)f^{p-1}x_{0,2p-2 }   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] we now want to give an explicit formula for the following diagram :        given @xmath349 , we can rewrite it as @xmath350 . applying @xmath351 to this we get : @xmath352!)}{([p-1]!)}(f^{m}x_{0,p-1})\\otimes\\rho_{i_{m+1}+1-p, ... ,i_{n}+1-p , p-1}\\\\ = & \\sum\\limits_{k_{1}, ... ,k_{m}}q^{\\big(mp-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{m}i_{j})-(\\sum\\limits_{l=1}^{m}k_{l})\\big)}\\frac{([p-1-m]!)([m]!)}{([p-1]!)}\\rho_{k_{1}, ... ,k_{m},p-1}\\otimes\\rho_{i_{m+1}+1-p, ... ,i_{n}+1-p , p-1}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] given @xmath353 , @xmath354 , @xmath355 , applying cups repeatedly to this , we get zero if @xmath356 or if @xmath357 .",
    "if @xmath340 and @xmath358 , then we have : @xmath359!)([m]!)}{([p-1]!)}\\nu\\\\ = & \\sum\\limits_{k_{1}, ... ,k_{m}}(-1)^{p-1}q^{\\big(p-1-m-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{m}i_{j})-(\\sum\\limits_{l=1}^{m}k_{l})\\big)}\\nu\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] note that for each choice of @xmath360 , there is a unique choice of @xmath361 satisfying the above conditions , i.e. @xmath362 , and so we have that : @xmath363 using this , we can simplify to get : @xmath364 given @xmath365 , let @xmath366 be the positions of the zeros . as @xmath282 , we have that the @xmath367-fold cap is given by : @xmath368 taking @xmath369 , this becomes : @xmath370 applying @xmath351 to this we get : @xmath371!)}{([p-1]!)}(f^{n}x_{0,p-1})\\otimes\\rho_{p-\\tilde{r}_{p-1-n}, ... ,p-\\tilde{r}_{1},p-1}\\bigg)\\\\ = & \\sum\\limits_{n=0}^{p-1}\\bigg(\\sum\\limits_{r_{1}, ...",
    ",r_{n}}\\sum\\limits_{s_{1}, ... ,s_{n}}(-1)^{p-1-n}q^{\\big(n(p-1)-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{n}r_{j})-(\\sum\\limits_{k=1}^{n}s_{k})\\big)}\\times\\\\ & \\times\\frac{([p-1-n]!)([n]!)}{([p-1]!)}\\rho_{s_{1}, ... ,s_{n},p-1}\\otimes\\rho_{p-\\tilde{r}_{p-1-n}, ... ,p-\\tilde{r}_{1},p-1}\\bigg)\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] as @xmath372 , this becomes : @xmath373!)([n]!)}{([p-1]!)}\\rho_{s_{1}, .. ,s_{n},2p-1-\\tilde{r}_{p-1-n}, ... ,2p-1-\\tilde{r}_{1},2p-2}\\bigg)\\\\ = & \\sum\\limits_{n=0}^{p-1}\\bigg(\\sum\\limits_{t_{1}, ...",
    ",t_{p-1}}(-1)^{p-1-n}q^{\\big(n(p-1)-\\frac{1}{2}(p^{2}-p)+(2p-1)(p-1-n)-(\\sum\\limits_{l=1}^{p-1}t_{l})\\big)}\\rho_{t_{1}, ... ,t_{p-1},2p-2}\\bigg)\\\\ = & \\sum\\limits_{n=0}^{p-1}\\bigg(\\sum\\limits_{t_{1}, ...",
    ",t_{p-1}}(-1)^{p-1}q^{\\big(1-p-\\frac{1}{2}(p^{2}-p)-(\\sum\\limits_{l=1}^{p-1}t_{l})\\big)}\\rho_{t_{1}, ... ,t_{p-1},2p-2}\\bigg)\\\\ = & \\sum\\limits_{t_{1}, ...",
    ",t_{p-1}}(-1)^{p-1}q^{\\big(1-p-\\frac{1}{2}(p^{2}-p)-(\\sum\\limits_{l=1}^{p-1}t_{l})\\big)}\\rho_{t_{1}, ... ,t_{p-1},2p-2}\\\\ = & q^{(1-p^{2})}\\frac{(-1)^{p-1}}{([p-1]!)}f^{p-1}x_{0,2p-2}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where we have taken @xmath374 , @xmath375 . combining this with the first part we get : @xmath376!)}f^{p-1}x_{0,2p-2}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] multiplying by @xmath377 ,",
    "this becomes : @xmath378!)f^{p-1}x_{0,2p-2}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] which is equal to the partial trace of @xmath188 .",
    "+ this map is also the second ( non - identity ) endomorphism on @xmath304 .",
    "details of this endomorphism for all @xmath379 , as well as homomorphisms between indecomposable modules , will be discussed in a future paper @xcite .",
    "there are a number of generalized relations for @xmath0 and its action on @xmath79 , which we record here .",
    "the quantum group @xmath0 and its relations can be used to give the following generalized conditions : @xmath380}{q - q^{-1}})\\big(q^{1-k}f^{k-1}k - q^{k-1}f^{k-1}k^{-1}\\big ) \\label{eq : a4}\\\\ fe^{k}&=e^{k}f+(\\frac{[k]}{q - q^{-1}})\\big(q^{1-k}e^{k-1}k^{-1}-q^{k-1}e^{k-1}k\\big ) \\label{eq : a5}\\\\ \\delta e^{k}&=\\sum\\limits_{i=0}^{k}\\lambda_{i , k}e^{i}\\otimes k^{i}e^{k - i } \\label{eq : a6}\\\\ \\delta f^{k}&=\\sum\\limits_{i=0}^{k}\\lambda_{i , k}k^{-i}f^{k - i}\\otimes f^{i } \\label{eq : a7}\\\\ \\lambda_{i , k}&=q^{(i^{2}-ik)}\\frac{([k]!)}{([i]!)([k - i ] ! ) } \\label{eq : a8}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the @xmath0 action on the basis elements satisfies the following : @xmath381!)x_{0,z } \\label{eq : a9}\\\\ f^{z - n}\\rho_{i_{1}, ...",
    ",i_{n},z}&=q^{\\big(nz-\\frac{1}{2}(n^{2}-n)-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{n}i_{j})\\big)}([z - n]!)x_{z , z } \\label{eq : a10}\\\\ f^{k}x_{0,z}&=\\sum\\limits_{1\\leq i_{j}\\leq z}q^{\\big(\\frac{1}{2}(k^{2}+k)-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{k}i_{j})\\big)}([k]!)\\rho_{i_{1}, ... ,i_{k},z } \\label{eq : a11}\\\\ e^{k}x_{z , z}&=\\sum\\limits_{1\\leq i_{j}\\leq z}q^{\\big(\\frac{1}{2}(z - k)(z - k+1)-(\\sum\\limits_{j=1}^{z - k}i_{j})\\big)}([k]!)\\rho_{i_{1}, ...",
    ",i_{z - k},z } \\label{eq : a12}\\\\ e^{k}x_{z+1,z+1}&=[k](e^{k-1}x_{z , z})\\otimes\\nu_{0}+q^{-k}(e^{k}x_{z , z})\\otimes\\nu_{1 } \\label{eq : a13}\\\\ & = q^{k - z-1}[k]\\nu_{0}\\otimes(e^{k-1}x_{z , z})+\\nu_{1}\\otimes(e^{k}x_{z , z } ) \\label{eq : a14}\\\\ f^{k}x_{0,z+1}&=(f^{k}x_{0,z})\\otimes\\nu_{0}+q^{k - z-1}[k](f^{k-1}x_{0,z})\\otimes\\nu_{1 } \\label{eq : a15}\\\\ & = q^{-k}\\nu_{0}\\otimes(f^{k}x_{0,z})+[k]\\nu_{1}\\otimes(f^{k-1}x_{0,z } ) \\label{eq : a16}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] these come from considering all contributions to the coefficient as different orderings of the integers @xmath103 , where each ordering describes the order in which the zeroes appeared . for the standard ordering with @xmath382 , its contribution to the coefficient is just @xmath383 .",
    "interchanging two integers in the ordering multiplies this by @xmath384 , and the coefficient comes from considering all possible permutations .",
    "+   + for integers @xmath385 , we have : @xmath386!)}{([n]!)([z - n ] ! ) } \\label{eq : a17}\\\\ \\xi_{n , z}= & q^{-2z}\\xi_{n-1,z-1}+\\xi_{n , z-1}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where the recurrence relation comes from considering the two cases in @xmath387 , when @xmath388 and when @xmath389 .",
    "the author s research was supported by epsrc dtp grant ep / k502819/1 .",
    "the author would like to thank the isaac newton institute for mathematical sciences , cambridge , for support and hospitality during the programme operator algebras : subfactors and their applications , where work on this paper was undertaken .",

    "the author thanks david evans and azat gainutdinov for their comments ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we describe the generators and prove a number of relations for the construction of a planar algebra from the restricted quantum group @xmath0 . </S>",
    "<S> this is a diagrammatic description of @xmath1 , where @xmath2 is a two dimensional @xmath0 module . </S>"
  ]
}
